comments: The digits of these numbers periodically repeat '123456790' until the middle digit at which point the digits periodically repeat '098765432' and then end in 1. - _J. Lowell_, May 16 2014Only nine first terms of this sequence are palindromes. - _Bui Quang Tuan_, Mar 30 2015
references: D. R. Kaprekar, On Wonderful Demlo numbers, Math. Stud., 6 (1938), 68.
N. J. A. Sloane, A Handbook of Integer Sequences, Academic Press, 1973 (includes this sequence).
N. J. A. Sloane and Simon Plouffe, The Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences, Academic Press, 1995 (includes this sequence).
links: Vincenzo Librandi, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..300
K. R. Gunjikar and D. R. Kaprekar, Theory of Demlo numbers, J. Univ. Bombay, Vol. VIII, Part 3, Nov. 1939, pp. 3-9. [Annotated scanned copy]
Simon Plouffe, Approximations de séries génératrices et quelques conjectures, Dissertation, Université du Québec à Montréal, 1992.
Simon Plouffe, 1031 Generating Functions and Conjectures, Université du Québec à Montréal, 1992.
Eric Weisstein's World of Mathematics, Demlo Number
mathematica: lst={};Do[p=((10^n-1)/9)^2;AppendTo[lst, p], {n, 0, 5!}];lst (* _Vladimir Joseph Stephan Orlovsky_, Sep 28 2008 *)Table[FromDigits[PadRight[{},n,1]]^2,{n,15}] (* _Harvey P. Dale_, Oct 16 2012 *)
prog: (Sage) [gaussian_binomial(n,1,10)^2 for n in xrange(1,14)] # _Zerinvary Lajos_, Jun 03 2009(PARI) a(n) = (10^n\9)^2 \\ _Charles R Greathouse IV_, Jul 25 2011(MAGMA) [((10^n - 1)/9)^2: n in [1..20]]; // _Vincenzo Librandi_, Jul 26 2011(Maxima) A002477(n):=((10^n - 1)/9)^2$makelist(A002477(n),n,1,10); /* _Martin Ettl_, Nov 12 2012 */
author: _N. J. A. Sloane_
extensions: Minor edits from _N. J. A. Sloane_, Aug 18 2009
